elements.content: We synthesized a new porous coordination polymer Cu[Cu(pdt)2], which shows relatively high electrical conductivity (6 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 300 K) by the introduction of electron donors and acceptors as building units. This compound is applicable as a porous electrode with high power density. In addition, this compound forms a triangular spin lattice and shows spin frustration.
elements.clean_text: We synthesized a new porous coordination polymer Cu[Cu(pdt)2], which shows relatively high electrical conductivity (6 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 300 K) by the introduction of electron donors and acceptors as building units. This compound is applicable as a porous electrode with high power density. In addition, this compound forms a triangular spin lattice and shows spin frustration.

elements.content: A novel porous coordination polymer Cu[Cu(pdt)2] (pdt = 2,3-pyrazinedithiol) was synthesized. This compound showed relatively high electrical conductivity (6 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 300 K) by the introduction of electron donors and acceptors as building units. This compound is applicable as a porous electrode with high power density.
elements.clean_text: A novel porous coordination polymer Cu[Cu(pdt)2] (pdt = 2,3-pyrazinedithiol) was synthesized. This compound showed relatively high electrical conductivity (6 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 300 K) by the introduction of electron donors and acceptors as building units. This compound is applicable as a porous electrode with high power density.

elements.content: Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal−organic frameworks have attracted considerable interest as a new class of micro- or mesoporous materials with huge surface area, regularity, and flexibility. These compounds have been extensively studied in the past decade because of their potential application for the fuel storage, separation, catalysis, etc. Recently, there has been growing interest in the physical properties of PCPs such as magnetic and photoluminescence responses. However, almost no attention has been paid to their electrical conductivity. To the best of my knowledge, there is only one PCP that shows relatively high electrical conductivity. If a PCP with high electric conductivity is realized, it is applicable to a porous electrode for batteries, fuel cells, capacitors, etc. Because PCPs have potentially huge surface areas, these compounds have a good potential as such electrodes with high power density. Here we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and physical properties of a novel electroconductive PCP, Cu[Cu(pdt)2] (pdt = 2,3-pyrazinedithiolate). In order to acquire the electroconductive property, we used electron donors and acceptors as building units.
elements.clean_text: Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal-organic frameworks have attracted considerable interest as a new class of micro- or mesoporous materials with huge surface area, regularity, and flexibility. These compounds have been extensively studied in the past decade because of their potential application for the fuel storage, separation, catalysis, etc. Recently, there has been growing interest in the physical properties of PCPs such as magnetic and photoluminescence responses. However, almost no attention has been paid to their electrical conductivity. To the best of my knowledge, there is only one PCP that shows relatively high electrical conductivity. If a PCP with high electric conductivity is realized, it is applicable to a porous electrode for batteries, fuel cells, capacitors, etc. Because PCPs have potentially huge surface areas, these compounds have a good potential as such electrodes with high power density. Here we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and physical properties of a novel electroconductive PCP, Cu[Cu(pdt)2] (pdt = 2,3-pyrazinedithiolate). In order to acquire the electroconductive property, we used electron donors and acceptors as building units.

elements.content: Figure shows the molecular structure of the electron acceptor unit [CuIII(pdt)2]−, which was reported by Rovira et al. They have shown that this molecule shows a reversible redox process between [CuII(pdt)2]2− and [CuIII(pdt)2]− at −0.33 V vs Ag/AgCl, indicating that [CuIII(pdt)2]− can act as an electron acceptor. In addition, this molecule has four coordination sites (N atoms of the pyrazine moiety). Therefore, this molecule can be used as the redox-active linker unit of the PCP. We chose the CuI ion as a connector unit. It has been known that the CuI ion acts as an electron donor, stable with a coordination number of 4 or 6 with different ligands. According to such a strategy, we have synthesized the novel PCP Cu[Cu(pdt)2].
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows the molecular structure of the electron acceptor unit [CuIII(pdt)2]-, which was reported by Rovira et al. They have shown that this molecule shows a reversible redox process between [CuII(pdt)2]2- and [CuIII(pdt)2]- at -0.33 V vs Ag/AgCl, indicating that [CuIII(pdt)2]- can act as an electron acceptor. In addition, this molecule has four coordination sites (N atoms of the pyrazine moiety). Therefore, this molecule can be used as the redox-active linker unit of the PCP. We chose the CuI ion as a connector unit. It has been known that the CuI ion acts as an electron donor, stable with a coordination number of 4 or 6 with different ligands. According to such a strategy, we have synthesized the novel PCP Cu[Cu(pdt)2].

elements.content: Molecular structure of [CuIII(pdt)2]−.

Single crystals of Cu[Cu(pdt)2] were synthesized by the slow diffusion of CuI and Na[Cu(pdt)2]·2H2O in an acetonitrile solution in an H-shaped cell. The crystal structure was determined in a single crystal by the Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). Magnetic susceptibility was acquired with a Quantum design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer. Electrical conductivity measurements were carried out using a Agilent 34420A nanovoltmeter. IR spectroscopy measurement was carried out with a KBr pellet using a ThermoNicolet NEXUS 670 FT/IR spectrometer.
elements.clean_text: Single crystals of Cu[Cu(pdt)2] were synthesized by the slow diffusion of CuI and Na[Cu(pdt)2]⋅2H2O in an acetonitrile solution in an H-shaped cell. The crystal structure was determined in a single crystal by the Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). Magnetic susceptibility was acquired with a Quantum design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer. Electrical conductivity measurements were carried out using a Agilent 34420A nanovoltmeter. IR spectroscopy measurement was carried out with a KBr pellet using a ThermoNicolet NEXUS 670 FT/IR spectrometer.

elements.content: Figure shows the crystal structure of Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. In this compound, N atoms of the pyrazine moiety coordinate to Cu ions, forming an infinite tetragonal lattice, as shown in Figure b. One-dimensional vacant spaces of 3.4 Å × 3.4 Å exist within the framework. Considering charge neutrality, there are two possibilities of electronic states of the compound, which are CuII[CuII(pdt)2] and CuI[CuIII(pdt)2]. We assumed that this compound is in the CuII[CuII(pdt)2] state through analysis of the Cu(1)−S distance. The Cu(1)−S distance of the present compound is 2.264 Å, which is longer than that of Na[CuIII(pdt)2]·2H2O (2.181 and 2.183 Å). As Rovira et al. have indicated, the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital of [CuIII(pdt)2]− is formed by an antibonding orbital of Cu d x 2−y 2 and S pσ. Therefore, the Cu(1)−S distance should become longer when [CuIII(pdt)2]− is reduced to [CuII(pdt)2]2−. Meanwhile, the valency of Cu(2) can be estimated to be CuII because the Cu−N4 geometry is slightly distorted square planar (distortion angle = 6.45°) rather than tetrahedral. In the X-ray crystal structure analysis, although some residual electron densities were observed within the micropore, these were probably due to the solvent molecules, but assignment to a specific molecule cannot be made (see the ).
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows the crystal structure of Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. In this compound, N atoms of the pyrazine moiety coordinate to Cu ions, forming an infinite tetragonal lattice, as shown in Figure b. One-dimensional vacant spaces of 3.4 Å × 3.4 Å exist within the framework. Considering charge neutrality, there are two possibilities of electronic states of the compound, which are CuII[CuII(pdt)2] and CuI[CuIII(pdt)2]. We assumed that this compound is in the CuII[CuII(pdt)2] state through analysis of the Cu(1)-S distance. The Cu(1)-S distance of the present compound is 2.264 Å, which is longer than that of Na[CuIII(pdt)2]⋅2H2O (2.181 and 2.183 Å). As Rovira et al. have indicated, the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital of [CuIII(pdt)2]- is formed by an antibonding orbital of Cu d x 2-y 2  and S pσ. Therefore, the Cu(1)-S distance should become longer when [CuIII(pdt)2]- is reduced to [CuII(pdt)2]2-. Meanwhile, the valency of Cu(2) can be estimated to be CuII because the Cu-N4 geometry is slightly distorted square planar (distortion angle = 6.45°) rather than tetrahedral. In the X-ray crystal structure analysis, although some residual electron densities were observed within the micropore, these were probably due to the solvent molecules, but assignment to a specific molecule cannot be made (see the ).

elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Crystal structure in Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. (b) Perspective view of the crystal structure of Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. Color code: green, Cu; yellow, S; gray, C; blue, N; pink, H.

elements.content: Figure shows the temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility in Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. Because magnetic susceptibility showed paramagnetic behavior in the entire temperature range, we were convinced that this compound was in the divalent CuII[CuII(pdt)2] state. Rovira et al. have synthesized the coordination polymer Cu[Cu(pds)2] (pds = 2,3-pyrazinediselenol) with a two-dimensional layered structure by electrolysis of Na[Cu(pds)2]·2H2O, which is in the diamagnetic CuI[CuIII(pds)2] state. We have also obtained the same crystal by the slow diffusion of Na[Cu(pds)2]·2H2O and CuI in an acetonitrile solution. This difference of the electronic state is probably due to the lower redox potential of [CuIII(pds)2]− (−0.54 V vs Ag/AgCl) than [CuIII(pdt)2]− (−0.33 V vs Ag/AgCl).
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows the temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility in Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. Because magnetic susceptibility showed paramagnetic behavior in the entire temperature range, we were convinced that this compound was in the divalent CuII[CuII(pdt)2] state. Rovira et al. have synthesized the coordination polymer Cu[Cu(pds)2] (pds = 2,3-pyrazinediselenol) with a two-dimensional layered structure by electrolysis of Na[Cu(pds)2]⋅2H2O, which is in the diamagnetic CuI[CuIII(pds)2] state. We have also obtained the same crystal by the slow diffusion of Na[Cu(pds)2]⋅2H2O and CuI in an acetonitrile solution. This difference of the electronic state is probably due to the lower redox potential of [CuIII(pds)2]- (-0.54 V vs Ag/AgCl) than [CuIII(pdt)2]- (-0.33 V vs Ag/AgCl).

elements.content: Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility in Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. Inset: three possible pathways of magnetic interactions: J 1, Cu(1)−S···S−Cu(1); J 2, Cu(1)−S−C−N−Cu(2); J 3, Cu(2)−N−C−C−N−Cu(2). The red line shows the best fit to the summation of eqs and .
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility in Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. Inset: three possible pathways of magnetic interactions: J 1, Cu(1)-S⋅⋅⋅S-Cu(1); J 2, Cu(1)-S-C-N-Cu(2); J 3, Cu(2)-N-C-C-N-Cu(2). The red line shows the best fit to the summation of eqs  and .

elements.content: Here we consider the possible pathways of magnetic interaction. As shown in the inset of Figure , three magnetic interactions are possible in the crystal. In order to estimate those magnetic couplings by theoretical calculations, we constructed three model structures consisting of two CuII ions, as illustrated in Figure S1 in the . Models A−C represent the magnetic interactions J 1, J 2, and J 3. For these models, the unrestricted B3LYP (UB3LYP) method was carried out on Gaussian98. All calculations were performed by use of the MIDI+p basis set for Cu atoms and the 4-31G basis set for others. Because the CuII ion has one spin, singlet and triplet spin couplings are expected in the models. Therefore, the J value in the Heisenberg Hamiltonian Ĥ = −2J ij Ŝ i ·Ŝ j can be calculated by the energy gap between the singlet and triplet states. Calculated total energies and ⟨S 2⟩ values are summarized in Table S1 in the . The estimated magnitudes of the magnetic interactions are J 1/k B = −353.2 K, J 2/k B = 25.1 K, and J 3/k B = −13.6 K. Although quantitativity may not be enough because this calculation was performed with two distinct units, we can assume that the relationship between the three values is J 1 ≫ J 2, J 3. In addition, considering the geometry of the magnetic interaction, there can be magnetic frustrations, e.g., −J 1−J 2−J 2− and −J 2−J 3−J 3−, because they form triangular lattices. Because J 1 is much larger than J 2, we can ignore the contribution of J 2. In this situation, the contribution of J 3 is independent of that of J 1. Therefore, we fitted the measured magnetic susceptibility by the summation of a one-dimensional Heisenberg antiferromagnetic model (Bonner−Fisher model) for J 1 and a two-dimensional Heisenberg antiferromagnetic model for J 3 as shown eqs and . χ 1 D = N g 2 μ B 2 k B T ( 0.25 + 0.14995 x 1 + 0.30094 x 1 2 1 + 1.9862 x 1 + 0.68854 x 1 2 + 6.0626 x 1 3 ) where x 1 = J 1/k B T χ 2 D = N g 2 μ B 2 k B T × ( 0.25 1 + 2 x 3 + 2 x 3 2 + 1.333 x 3 3 + 0.250 x 3 4 − 0.4833 x 3 5 + 0.003797 x 3 6 ) where x 3 = J 3/k B T.

Models A-C represent the magnetic interactions J 1, J 2, and J 3. For these models, the unrestricted B3LYP (UB3LYP) method was carried out on Gaussian98. All calculations were performed by use of the MIDI+p basis set for Cu atoms and the 4-31G basis set for others. Because the CuII ion has one spin, singlet and triplet spin couplings are expected in the models. Therefore, the J value in the Heisenberg Hamiltonian Ĥ = -2J  ij  Ŝ  i ⋅Ŝ  j  can be calculated by the energy gap between the singlet and triplet states. Calculated total energies and ⟨S 2⟩ values are summarized in Table S1 in the . The estimated magnitudes of the magnetic interactions are J 1/k B = -353.2 K, J 2/k B = 25.1 K, and J 3/k B = -13.6 K. Although quantitativity may not be enough because this calculation was performed with two distinct units, we can assume that the relationship between the three values is J 1 ≫ J 2, J 3. In addition, considering the geometry of the magnetic interaction, there can be magnetic frustrations, e.g., -J 1-J 2-J 2- and -J 2-J 3-J 3-, because they form triangular lattices. Because J 1 is much larger than J 2, we can ignore the contribution of J 2. In this situation, the contribution of J 3 is independent of that of J 1. Therefore, we fitted the measured magnetic susceptibility by the summation of a one-dimensional Heisenberg antiferromagnetic model (Bonner-Fisher model) for J 1 and a two-dimensional Heisenberg antiferromagnetic model for J 3 as shown eqs  and .  1     χ   1 D   =     N g   2       μ   B     2       k   B   T    (   0.25 + 0.14995   x   1   + 0.30094     x   1     2     1 + 1.9862   x   1   + 0.68854     x   1     2   + 6.0626     x   1     3     )    where x 1 = J 1/k B T  2     χ   2 D   =     N g   2       μ   B     2       k   B   T   ×  (   0.25   1 + 2   x   3   + 2     x   3     2   + 1.333     x   3     3   + 0.250     x   3     4   - 0.4833     x   3     5   + 0.003797     x   3     6     )    where x 3 = J 3/k B T.

elements.content: The parameters obtained are J 1/k B = −162.6 K, J 3/k B = −4.1 K, and g = 2.007. Hendrickson et al. reported the pyrazine-bridged two-dimensional compound CuII(pyz)2(ClO4)2 and showed that this compound has weak antiferromagnetic interaction (J = −7.6 K), which is consistent with our result.
elements.clean_text: The parameters obtained are J 1/k B = -162.6 K, J 3/k B = -4.1 K, and g = 2.007. Hendrickson et al. reported the pyrazine-bridged two-dimensional compound CuII(pyz)2(ClO4)2 and showed that this compound has weak antiferromagnetic interaction (J = -7.6 K), which is consistent with our result.

elements.content: Figure shows the temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity in Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. This compound showed relatively high electrical conductivity (6 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 300 K). The temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity showed semiconductive behavior, and an activation energy was determined to be 193 meV from the Arrhenius fitting of the conductivity. The reason for such a relatively high electrical conductivity is probably the charge bistability between CuI[CuIII(pdt)2] and CuII[CuII(pdt)2].
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows the temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity in Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. This compound showed relatively high electrical conductivity (6 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 300 K). The temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity showed semiconductive behavior, and an activation energy was determined to be 193 meV from the Arrhenius fitting of the conductivity. The reason for such a relatively high electrical conductivity is probably the charge bistability between CuI[CuIII(pdt)2] and CuII[CuII(pdt)2].

elements.content: Temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity in Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. The red line shows the best fit to the Arrhenius model.
elements.clean_text: 4  Temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity in Cu[Cu(pdt)2]. The red line shows the best fit to the Arrhenius model.

elements.content: Figure shows the IR spectrum of CuII[CuII(pdt)2] at room temperature. A broad peak at approximately 0.7 eV was observed, but it was not observed in Na[Cu(pdt)2]. We assigned this peak as the charge-transfer (CT) band from CuII[CuII(pdt)2] to CuI[CuIII(pdt)2] states because the peak energy is too low to assign to an intramolecular transition. Torrance et al. have reported that a series of CT complexes with alternately stacked structures have CT transitions in the IR region and some of them show phase transition accompanied by CT. In the present case, however, no anomaly was observed in the electrical conductivity and magnetic susceptibility, showing that the CuII[CuII(pdt)2] state is stable in the measured temperature range (2−400 K). This is probably due to the large rearrangement energy between square-planar CuII and tetrahedral CuI geometries.
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows the IR spectrum of CuII[CuII(pdt)2] at room temperature. A broad peak at approximately 0.7 eV was observed, but it was not observed in Na[Cu(pdt)2]. We assigned this peak as the charge-transfer (CT) band from CuII[CuII(pdt)2] to CuI[CuIII(pdt)2] states because the peak energy is too low to assign to an intramolecular transition. Torrance et al. have reported that a series of CT complexes with alternately stacked structures have CT transitions in the IR region and some of them show phase transition accompanied by CT. In the present case, however, no anomaly was observed in the electrical conductivity and magnetic susceptibility, showing that the CuII[CuII(pdt)2] state is stable in the measured temperature range (2-400 K). This is probably due to the large rearrangement energy between square-planar CuII and tetrahedral CuI geometries.

Crystallographic data of Cu[Cu(pdt)2] (CIF), model structures used for the theoretical calculations, calculated total energies, and refinement of the electron density within the pore. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Electroconductive Porous Coordination Polymer Cu[Cu(pdt)2] Composed of Donor and Acceptor Building Units
Communication
